metadata.title: Solutions of a disease model with fractional white noise

body_text.text: Fractional-stochastic calculus consist of fractional-order derivatives, integral operators or fractional Brownian motion and a noise term representing uncertainty or randomness in modeling. These differential equations have found an outstanding role in efficiently modeling of many different phenomena in science, engineering and economics.

Epidemic diseases including Coronavirus, Brucellosis, Chickenpox, Dengue, Ebola, Mumps, Influenza, Measles, Plague, SARS, Tetanus, Tuberculosis, Zika, West Nile Virus were studied in terms of some efficient mathematical models in the related scientific literature. These systems were generated by taking into account some facts such as duration of disease, availability and resistance against vaccination, immune systems of individuals in the population and so on. There are mathematical models employing deterministic [4], [5], [6], [7], stochastic [1], [2], [3], fractional-order [8], [9], [10], [11], [12], [13], [14], [15] system of differential equations. Almost each of these models were generated by compartmental models considering each compartment as individuals of susceptible (denoted by S), infected (I), exposed (E), and recovered (R) ones.

In the present research work, new SIRS models both in deterministic and fractional-stochastic settings are proposed. We are concerned with endemic equilibrium and disease-free fixed points and numerical solutions of these models with different type of numerical techniques. We also consider additive fractional white noise representation of the SIRS model and obtain numerical and exact solutions of these models. In the modeling of epidemic diseases via compartmental type mathematical models, there exists not any study considering fractional white noise, Wick product and fractional-order operators all together. Our driving motivation in this paper is to investigate the applicability of these significant and powerful techniques to the modeling of epidemic diseases. Our contributions in this paper may be listed as: i) Generating a new SIRS model. ii.) Considering this system in terms of stochastic equations and fractional white noise. iii) Studying chaos at disease-free and endemic steady state points. iv) Solving perturbed systems (perturbed from deterministic to fractional-stochastic) both numerically and explicitly (exactly). We provided Figures illustrating the behavior of compartments in different environments. From this listed contributions, we can say that the present paper is totally a new contribution to mathematical biologists studying compartment models by fractional and stochastic differential equations. We believe that researchers in this area will employ the present paper and extend it to different models.

We are concerned with a SIRS system described as:(1)dS(t)dt=ρM−νS(t)I(t)M+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t),dI(t)dt=νS(t)I(t)M−dI(t)−ξI(t),dR(t)dt=dI(t)R(t)−kR(t)−ξR(t),in which S(t), I(t), R(t), stands for individuals of susceptible, infected and recovered, respectively, R(t)+I(t)+S(t)=M, represents population of all individuals, ρ and ξ are the birth and death rates, respectively, (we assumed that they are equal to each other,) ν is the probability of transmission rate between compartments S(t) and I(t), d is rate of recovery from the disease, k is the rate of being susceptible after recovered from disease. In our SIRS model, we assume that the healed people are not infected and can not spread the disease any further among other individuals in the population.
Defining new variablesa:=νM,e:=k+ξ,c:=d+ξ,N:=ρM,re-expression of the system (1) is:(2)dS(t)dt=N−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t),dI(t)dt=aS(t)I(t)−cI(t),dR(t)dt=dI(t)R(t)−eR(t).

Fractional-order calculus [16], [17], [18], [48], [51] (or differential equations) generated by fractional-order derivative and integral operators found a significant place in applied and computational mathematics in recent years. They were employed in many different scientific work at mathematics, physics, economics and engineering. Fractional-order operators considers historical effects and have non-local computational ability which makes these operators more powerful and desirable in the modeling applications. There are many different fractional derivative or integral operators such as Grünwald-Letnikov, Riemann-Liouville, Caputo, Atangana-Baleanu and so on. Let g:(0,∞)↦R be a function. Fractional-order integral operator of order β for g is defined byJβg(t)=1Γ(β)∫0t(t−σ)β−1g(σ)dσ,inhere Γ( · ) denotes Gamma function.
For (m∈N), Caputo-type derivative operator of order β, m−1<β<m, of g(t) is given byDβg(t)=Jm−βdmdtmg(t).

Next, we express derivatives on left-hand-side of system (2) by Caputo-type fractional-order time derivatives. Therefore, we write the fractional-order SIRS model as(3)DtαS(t)=N−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t),DtαI(t)=aI(t)S(t)−cI(t),DtαR(t)=dI(t)R(t)−eR(t).Disease-free equilibrium (or fixed-point or steady-state point) is determined by letting rightmost side of system (3) equal to 0, when I(t) ≡ 0. Hence, disease-free equilibrium is given byE0=(S(t),I(t),R(t))=(Nξ,0,0).
Theorem 2.1
Consider
Dtαy(t)=g(t,y(t)),
y(t0)=y0, 0 < α ≤ 1, where
Dtα

where λi, is the eigenvalue of Jacobian g(t, y(t)) at

Jacobian in E
0, isJ(Nξ,0,0)=[−ξ−aNξkNξ0aNξ−c000−e].

From equation det[J(Nξ,0,0)−λI3×3]=0, we obtain the eigenvalues asλ1=−ξ,λ2=aNξ−c,λ3=−e.It is clear that λ1=−ξ<0, and λ3=−e<0, since ξ > 0 and e > 0.|Arg(λ1)|=|Arg(λ3)|=π>πα2,since0<α<1.However, if λ2=aNξ−c>0, the system becomes unstable, since|Arg(λ2)|=0<πα2,forall0<α<1.Hence, system is stable locally asymptotically only if λ
2 < 0, that is possible when c>aNξ.

Now, we consider a quite useful and important number; namely, the basic reproduction number described in [40] among many others. It is a dimensionless number and typically denoted with R0. If R0<0, then, the disease disappears and if R0>0, the disease is disseminated amongst susceptible individuals (hosts.) Finally, if R0=0, this implies that an endemic disease exists in the population with a constant rate and infected hosts convey the disease to the susceptible individuals.

Hence, we conclude from the above computations that R0, for (3) isR0:=cξaN.Because R0>0, the disease is disseminated amongst susceptible individuals. In particular, if any one of the coefficients ξ or c is equal to 0, then R0=0, this implies that an endemic disease exists in the population with a constant rate and infected hosts convey the disease to the susceptible individuals. Next, we consider the endemic steady-state point which is obtained when I(t)≢0. Hence, the endemic equilibrium point is(4)E1=(S(t),I(t),R(t))=(ca,ed,ξc+akc+acξ−Nakcd),which is determined by letting the rightmost part (3) equal to 0.J(S(t),I(t),R(t))=[−aI(t)+kR(t)−ξ−aS(t)kS(t)aI(t)aS(t)−c00dR(t)dI(t)−e].Therefore,J(E1)=[A*−ckcaaed000B*0],where,A*=−ace+ξc+akc+acξ−Na−ξcdcd,B*=ξc+akc+acξ−Nakc.
It is possible to calculate the eigenvalues of this matrix for special parameter values and then study on stability, see e.g. [26], of the system.
Notice that(S(t),I(t),R(t))∈R+3={(a1,a2,a3):ai≥0foreveryi=1,2,3}.

Generalized Mean Value Theorem: ([20]) Suppose h(t) and Dtαh(t) are continuous functions on [a, b]. Then, it is possible to write thath(t)=h(a)+1Γ(α)Dtαh(ξ)(t−a)α,0≤ξ≤tforeveryt∈[a,b].Now, let us notice that if h(t) ∈ C[0, b] and Dtαh(t)∈C[0,b] for 0 < α ≤ 1. The theorem implies that if Dtαh(t)≥0 for every y ∈ (0, b), h is non-decreasing. Furthermore, if Dtαh(t)≤0 for every y ∈ (0, b), h is non-increasing for every t ∈ [0, b].Theorem 3.1
There exists a unique solution of
(3)
belonging to
R+3.

Proof
DtαS(t)|S(t)=0=M≥0,DtαI(t)|I(t)=0=0,DtαR(t)|R(t)=0=0.After showing existence of non-negative solutions of the system, we present numerical solutions of (3). □

Computational or numerical solutions of models in fractional calculus have been an active research area for scientists in recent years [21], [22], [23], [24]. We employ a numerical solution method; namely, trapezoidal rule, introduced and applied in, e.g. [19], to obtain numerical solutions of the system (3). Now, let us state the system (3) as(5)DtαX(t)=g(X(t)),X(j)(t0)=X0(j),j=0,1,…,k−1,where g ∈ C
2[0, T]. Consider Δ:=cm. The discretization of the functions at the nodal points are used in the sense of{(ti,X(ti))}i=0m={(ti,Xi)}i=0m,ti=iΔ,i=0,1,2,…,m.Approximate solution of u(t) depending on (α, g, Δ) is given byN(α,g,Δ)=∑i=0m−1(t−t0)ii!X(i)(t0)+Δαg(c)Γ(α+2)+am∑i=1m−1Δαg(ti)Γ(α+2)bm−iα,in whicham=Δαg(0)[(−1+m)α+1−mα(−1+m−α)]Γ(α+2),bm−i=(−1+m−i)α+1−2(m−i)α+1+(m+1−i)α+1,for m=1,2,3,….
N(α,g,Δ)−Er(α,g,Δ),is approximate solution of (5) with|Er(α,g,Δ)|≤C(α)∥g″∥∞Δ2Cα=O(Δ2).

The following parameters are considering: N=150,
a=10/(58)(365) per year, k=3/(84)(365) per year, ϵ=1/22 per year, c=1/23 per year, d=1/3 per year and e=0.24 pear year, with S(0)=30,
I(0)=1.0 and R(0)=1.0, all values were assumed. The dynamics of the new fractional SIRS model given by Eq. (3) for several values of α  ∈ (0, 1], arbitrarily chosen, are plotted in Figs. 1
a-1 c.

The mathematical models describing epidemic diseases are generated by deterministic, stochastic or fractional-order system of ordinary differential equations. Each of these models explains the advantages of employed differential equation in their system. Fractional-order models indicates that these types of models takes into account past effects of the system, stochastic models [27], [28], [29], [52] emphasis on probabilistic transmissions of the diseases among the individuals in the population and so on. To the best of our knowledge, there exists not any mathematical model for a epidemic disease which considers both fractional-order operators and white noise together. Now, we perturb the fractional-order system (3) into a new system (mostly known as fractional-stochastic system) by an additive white noise to the-rightmost side of each equation in the system. Our major aim in the section is to illustrate the use of both fractional-order operators and white noise together and test the effectiveness of resulting new model. It is possible to generate some other fractional-order stochastic SIRS models simply by a new type of fractional order operator or the changing the way of adding the noise to the system. We consider the perturbed fractional-order stochastic SIRS model:(6)DtαS(t)=N−aS(t)I(t)+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t)−c1S(t)I(t)dW1(t),DtαI(t)=aS(t)I(t)−cI(t)−c2S(t)I(t)dW2(t),DtαR(t)=dI(t)R(t)−eR(t)−c3R(t)I(t)dW3(t),where dWi is a Wiener process for each i=1,2,3. Disease-free point, obtained when I(t) ≡ 0, is the same point with the deterministic system (3). Stability of the system (6) may be investigated by Lyapunov stability method [25] which is applied to the system (6):(7)S(t)DtαS(t)+I(t)DtαI(t)+R(t)DtαR(t)=S2(t)+S(t)I(t)+S(t)R(t)−aS2(t)I(t)+kR(t)S2(t)−ξS2(t)+c1S2(t)I(t)dW1(t)+aS(t)I2(t)−cI2(t)+c2S(t)I2(t)dW2(t)+dI(t)R2(t)−eR2(t)+c3I(t)R2(t)dW3(t)=S2(t)(1−aI(t)−ξ−c1I(t)dW1(t)+I(t)+R(t))+I2(t)(aS(t)−c−c2S(t)dW2(t))+R2(t)(dI(t)−e−c3I(t)dW3(t))≤0.
Hence, the system (6) is stable to 0, when(8)1−aI(t)−ξ−c1I(t)dW1(t)+I(t)+R(t)<0,aS(t)−c−c2S(t)dW2(t)<0,dI(t)−e−c3I(t)dW3(t)<0.

We present an approximate solution of (6). By employing an Euler type numerical method, discretized equations are expressed asS(n)=[N(n)−aI(n−1)S(n−1)+kS(n−1)R(n−1)−ξS(n−1)−c1S(n−1)I(n−1)Δtζn+c122S(n−1)I(n−1)(ζn2−1)Δt]Δα−∑m=1nτ(m)S(n−m)I(n)=[aS(n−1)I(n−1)−cI(n−1)+c2S(n−1)I(n−1)Δtμn+c222S(n−1)I(n−1)(μn2−1)Δt]Δα−∑m=1nτ(m)I(n−m)R(n)=[dI(n−1)R(n−1)−eR(n−1)−c3R(n−1)I(n−1)Δtηn+c322R(n−1)I(n−1)(ηn2−1)Δt]Δα−∑m=1nτ(m)R(n−m)where ζn, μn, ηn are Gaussian random variables N(0,1). The element, ∑m=1nτ(m)A(n−m),A∈{S,I,R}, on the rightmost side of the equations represent the historical (or memory effects) of the mapping at each time step. τ is defined asτ(0)=1,τ(m)=[1−1+αm]τ(m−1),1≤m,with the initial conditions S(0)=S0,I(0)=I0,R(0)=R0.

Following parameters are considering: N=150,
a=10/(58)(365) per year, k=3/(84)(365) per year, ϵ=1/22 per year, c=1/23 per year, d=1/3 per year and e=0.24 pear year, with S(0)=30,
I(0)=1.0 and R(0)=1.0, all values were assumed. The dynamics of the new fractional-order stochastic SIRS model given by Eq. (6) for several values of α  ∈ (0, 1], arbitrarily chosen, are plotted in Figs. 2
a-2 c.

Most of the SIR, SIS, SEIR, SEIRS type of epidemic disease models in the mathematical biology are generated by systems of ordinary differential equations. It is possible to assume that these models involve uncertainty, noise effects, undetermined outside forces and randomness in almost each time of the duration of the disease. These uncertainties may be strength of immune system of individuals, availability and resistance against vaccination, transmission rates of disease among individuals, and so on. The mathematical models in epidemiology is produced by means of either deterministic or stochastic systems of differential equations. We consider the deterministic fractional SIRS system (2) by an additive fractional white noise [30], [31], [32], [33] which is stated via Wick product. By using the equality:(9)dBH(t)dt=WH(t),we present a numerical solution of the Wick product added SIRS model with an Euler type numerical method. In the history of research so far, there exists not any mathematical model considering Wick product interpretation of any epidemic disease. From this point of view, the present study is the first research work associating Wick product with a SIRS model.
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion
SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: Another quite useful and important tool in fBm and its applications is a product known as Wick product. It is a paired (binary) type operation, typically denoted with a symbol ⋄, and it is employed in famous Wiener-Ito-Chaos decomposition of function in L2−measurable space. Wick product is a significant phenomena in stochastic and fractional stochastic calculus, mostly applied in the solutions of nonlinear differential equations in financial mathematics and fluid mechanics. A detailed treatment to Wick product and its applications can be seen in ([34], [35], [36], [37], [38], [39], [49]). In this paper, we employ the Wick product in the fractional Brownian motion settings to represent fractional white noise. Addressing an fractional Wick-Ito integral, following rule holds:∫RY(t,w)dBH(t)=∫RY(t)⋄WH(t)dt=∫MY(tdBH(t)),in which the operator M is defined as(10)Mf(x)=CH∫Rf(t)|t−x|3/2−Hdt,where,CH=[2Γ(H−1/2)Cos(1/2)π(H−1/2)]−1[Γ(2H+1)Sin(πH)]1/2,andHδ(k)(w)=∫Rηk(t)dB(t),in whichηh(x)=π−1/4((n−1)!)−1/2hn−1(2x)e−x2/2,n=1,2,….
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: The hn(x) defined in this equation is given ashn(x)=(−1)nex2/2dndxn(e−x2/2),n=0,1,2,…
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: Fractional white noise WH(t) also has a series representation given byWH(t)=∑k=1∞Mηk(t)Hδ(k)(w),where the operator M is defined by Equation (10).
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: Now, by adding fractional white noise to the terms in the rightmost side of the system of equations (2), we get(11)dS(t)dt=N−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t)⋄WH(t),dI(t)dt=aI(t)S(t)−cI(t)⋄WH(t),dR(t)dt=dI(t)R(t)−eR(t)⋄WH(t),with some suitable supplementary conditions S(0)=S0,I(0)=I0,R(0)=R0. This system may be restated as(12)dS(t)=(N−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t))dt−ξS(t)⋄WH(t)dt,dI(t)=aI(t)S(t)dt−cI(t)⋄WH(t)dt,dR(t)=dI(t)R(t)dt−eR(t)⋄WH(t)dt.
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: Writing in the integral form:(13)S(t)=S0+∫0t(N−aS(s)I(s)+kR(s)S(s))ds−ξ∫0tS(s)⋄WH(s)ds,I(t)=I0+∫0taS(s)I(s)ds−∫0tcI(s)⋄WH(s)ds,R(t)=R0+∫0tdI(s)R(s)ds−∫0teR(s)⋄WH(s)ds.
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text: It is further possible that we can express system (13) as(14)S(t)=S0+∫0t(N−aS(s)I(s)+kR(s)S(s))ds−ξ∫0tS(s)⋄dBH(s)ds,I(t)=I0+∫0taS(s)I(s)ds−∫0tcI(s)⋄dBH(s)ds,R(t)=R0+∫0tdI(s)R(s)ds−∫0teR(s)⋄dBH(s)ds.
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text:
Now, we solve the system (14) numerically employing an Euler’s type of numerical solution technique as follows:Sn(t)=Sn−1(t)+S0−[N−aSn−1(t)In−1(t)+kRn−1(t)S(n−1(t))](tn−tn−1)
−ξSn−1(t)⋄(BnH(t)−Bn−1H(t)),
(15)In(t)=In−1(t)+I0+aSn−1(t)In−1(t)(tn−tn−1)+cIn−1(t)⋄(BnH(t)−Bn−1H(t)),
Rn(t)=Rn−1(t)+R0+dIn−1(t)Rn−1(t)(tn−tn−1)+eRn−1(t)⋄(BnH(t)−Bn−1H(t)).
body_text.section: SIRS model with fractional Brownian motion

body_text.text:
The following parameters are considering: N=150,
a=10/(58)(365) per year, k=3/(84)(365) per year, ϵ=1/22 per year, c=1/23 per year, d=1/3 per year and e=0.24 pear year, with S(0)=30,
I(0)=1.0 and R(0)=1.0, all values were assumed. The dynamics of the new SIRS model with additive fractional white noise stated in terms of the Wick product given by Eq. (15) for several values of H  ∈ (0, 1], arbitrarily chosen, are plotted in Figs. 3
a-3 c.

In this section, we present two different exact (or sometimes known as explicit) solutions of the system given by (11). In the first technique that we call it direct method, we solve the equations in the system (11) separately by considering each equation in the system alone. Now, the first stochastic equation(16)dS(t)=[N−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t)]dt−ξS(t)⋄WH(t)dt,appearing in system of equations (11). By using the identity given for total population of all indivials, we get thatdS(t)=(ρS(t)+ρI(t)+ρR(t)−aS(t)I(t)+kR(t)S(t))dt−ξS(t)⋄WH(t)dt.
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Without loss of generality, let us ignore the term ρI(t)+ρR(t), since we deal with the population of susceptible individuals and by the fact that infected and recovered individuals are opposite to one another. Then, dS(t) may be written asdS(t)=[ρS(t)−aI(t)S(t)+kR(t)S(t))dt−ξS(t)]⋄WH(t)dt,dS(t)dt=S(t)⋄[ρ−aI(t)+kR(t)−ξWH(t)],S(t)=S0⋄exp⋄[∫0t(ρ−aI(s)+kR(s))ds−ξ∫0tdBH(s)],S(t)=S0⋄exp⋄[∫0t(ρ−aI(s)+kR(s))ds−ξBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: In a similar manner, the second equationdI(t)=aI(t)S(t)dt−cI(t)⋄WH(t)dt,in the system (11) may be expressed asdI(t)dt=I(t)⋄[aS(t)−cWH(t)],I(t)=I0⋄exp⋄[∫0taI(s)ds−c∫0tdBH(s)],I(t)=I0⋄exp⋄[∫0taI(s)ds−cBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Finally, the third equationdR(t)=dI(t)R(t)dt−eR(t)⋄WH(t)dt,in the system (11) may be expressed asdR(t)dt=R(t)⋄[dI(t)−eWH(t)],R(t)=R0⋄exp⋄[∫0tI(s)ds−e∫0tdBH(s)],R(t)=R0⋄exp⋄[∫0tI(s)ds−eBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Next, we present exact (or explicit) solutions of the system (2) having multiplicative fractional white noise by another method; namely, semi-martingale method [47].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Let us write the equations of the system (2) with multiplicative fractional white noise. First equation in the system (2):dS(t)dt=S(t)+I(t)+R(t)−aS(t)I(t)+kR(t)S(t)−ξS(t)dBH(t)dt,dS(t)=[I(t)+R(t)+(1+kR(t)−aI(t))S(t)]dt−ξS(t)dBH(t),from which S(t) is obtained asS(t)=Ψ1(t)[S0+∫0t[S(s)+I(s)](Ψ1−1)(s)ds],where,Ψ1(t)=exp[∫0t[1+kR(s)−aI(s)]ds+ξBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Now, we express the second equation in the system (2) with multiplicative fractional white noise as follows:dI(t)dt=aS(t)I(t)−cI(t)dBH(t)dtdI(t)=[I(t)+(aS(t)−1)I(t)]dt−cI(t)dBH(t),from which I(t) is obtained asI(t)=Ψ2(t)[I0+∫0tI(s)Ψ2−1(s)ds],in whichΨ2(t)=exp[∫0t(aS(s)−1)ds−cBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Finally, the third equation in the system (2) with multiplicative fractional white noise is:dR(t)dt=dR(t)I(t)−eR(t)dBH(t)dtdR(t)=[R(t)+(dI(t)−1)R(t)]dt−eR(t)dBH(t),from which R(t) is obtained asR(t)=Ψ3(t)[R0+∫0tR(s)Ψ3−1(s)ds],in whichΨ3(t)=Exp[∫0t(dI(s)−1)ds−eBH(t)].
body_text.section: Explicit solutions of fractional stochastic SIR model

body_text.text: Fractional-stochastic differential equations and fractional Brownian motion are very powerful modeling tools in science, engineering and economics. They found a very widespread applications areas in each of these areas. In the present research study, we pointed an original SIRS model for a modeling of a possible epidemic disease under certain assumptions. We study on chaos (stability) analysis, numerical and explicit solutions of fractional-stochastic SIRS models in fractional calculus and fractional Brownian motion settings.

As a future extension of the present research work, we plan to set up connections between SIRS types models and control optimization problems. Furthermore, because each of these epidemic disease models include parameters, we will study on problems of parameter estimation, identification and parameter sensitivity analyses of fractional-stochastic models in mathematical biology.
M.A. Akinlar: Conceptualization, Data curation. Mustafa Inc: Formal analysis. J.F. Gómez-Aguilar: Writing - original draft, Visualization. B. Boutarfa: Formal analysis, Writing - original draft.
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interests regarding the publication of this paper.

FIGREF1.text: Fig. 2: Numerical simulation for the new fractional-order stochastic SIRS model given by Eq. (6) for (α=1,0.90,0.80,0.70 and 0.60).

FIGREF2.text: Fig. 3: Simulation for SIRS model with additive fractional white noise stated via Wick product given by Eq. (15) for (H=1,0.95,0.90,0.85 and 0.75).

BIBREF2.title: Deterministic and stochastic SIR epidemic models with power function transmission and recovery rates
BIBREF2.venue: Mathematics of Continuous and Discrete Dynamical Systems

BIBREF4.title: Analysis of a stochastic SIR model with fractional brownian motion
